nodes.text: The widespread use of constant elasticity of substitution (CES) functions in Integrated Assessment Models (IAMs) causes a modeling artifact that falsely produces monotonically and exponentially increasing carbon prices and misrepresents technical energy transitions

CES functions are share-preserving and imply a marginal rate of technical substitution (MRTS) that depends on the input ratio, requiring exponentially increasing amounts of the substitute as substitution progresses

IAMs have multiple external shortcomings including controversial discount rate choices, arbitrary climate damage functions that understate high-warming impacts, and poor handling of catastrophic tail risks

Mathematical derivation: for a two-input CES production Y = [alpha*F^-rho + (1-alpha)*R^-rho]^(-1/rho), MRTS and the relative price PF/PR follow formulas that imply substitution elasticity epsilon_F,R = -1/(1+rho) and PF/PR = (alpha/(1-alpha))*(F/R)^(-rho-1)

Stylized CES example substituting fossil energy (F) with renewables (R) shows: (i) exponentially increasing R required, (ii) substitution saturates far from complete, (iii) carbon price starts low and rises exponentially, and (iv) results are highly sensitive to elasticity and initial shares

Empirical evidence from mainstream IAMs (GTEM-C, MIT EPPA, GCAM, MERGE and others) exhibits the same artifact: carbon prices rising to hundreds or thousands of dollars per ton late-century and limited apparent penetration of renewables without backstop technologies

Policy-relevant implications of the CES artifact are: price diversion (overemphasis on carbon pricing over physical planning), sticker shock (resignation due to very high projected prices), and technological myopia (models favor incumbent, pre-specified technologies like CCS, nuclear, or biomass)
Because CES is unsuitable for long-term technical substitution, IAM results that rely on CES produce misleading marginal carbon price trajectories and therefore unreliable policy guidance
Technological substitutions historically follow S-curve diffusion (logistic, Gompertz, Bass models) with dynamic elasticity that becomes easier as adoption increases, contrary to CES assumptions

A practical alternative within IAM frameworks is to use a dynamically varying elasticity of substitution (linearly or exponentially decreasing rho) to reproduce S-curve transition behavior and avoid CES artifacts

A fundamentally different and preferable approach is to model energy transitions using physical energy principles and high-resolution physics-driven models that account for storage, system integration, and explicit deployment targets

Model modification demonstration: implementing dynamic elasticity in the sample CES formulation yields substitution and carbon price trajectories that align with expected diffusion dynamics and cap carbon price by substitute technology cost

Assumption and limitation: many IAMs also embed other modeling choices (exogenous GDP growth, discounting, damage function shapes) that interact with substitution formulations and can compound misleading results
